title: Absolute Path Hell
body:
Does anyone know the latest version of browserify that used relative path ? 

I am not going to comment on if relative path is better or worse then absolute path. 

I am sure there are good reasons why everyone switched to absolute path for browserify. 

Its just that I was using browserify during 4.0.0 release and wrote a module then. 

I tried passing the flag {path:false} but it does not work on windows :( 

So for now its best to stick to older browserify versions. However the latest browserify version is 12.0.0 ! 

so I want to use the latest browserify version but not from the one that uses absolute path.

title: dedupe causes issues with bundle-collapser
body:
Exact file duplicates across modules are deduped, but called with differing contexts. This is usually fine, because the require function will look up modules by name.

If `bundle-collapser` is included the deduped module has it's requires inlined with the row's original context. When the wrapper comes along it replaces the context, but as the requires are now inlined no lookup happens.

The dupe rows are marked with a "dedupe" property by `deps-sort`, but the original row is not marked. As a result `bundle-collapser` currently can not do any alternative work.

@substack do you have any recommendations on how to proceed?

title: Cannot rebrowserify bundle with querystring module
body:
I'm in a situation where I have module A that provides a browserified build on npm. I have another module B that depends on module A and also provides a browserified build.

I found an issue with having module A requiring the [querystring](https://github.com/substack/querystring) module. You can reproduce with the following steps:

``` shell
npm install querystring
echo "var qs = require('querystring');" > index.js
browserify index.js -o bundle.js
echo "var bundle = require('./bundle');" > index.js
browserify index.js -o bundle2.js
```

This returns the error:

``` shell
Error: Cannot find module './decode' from '/Users/rahat/Downloads/temp'
    at /Users/rahat/.nvm/versions/node/v0.12.7/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:55:21
    at load (/Users/rahat/.nvm/versions/node/v0.12.7/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:69:43)
    at onex (/Users/rahat/.nvm/versions/node/v0.12.7/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:92:31)
    at /Users/rahat/.nvm/versions/node/v0.12.7/lib/node_modules/browserify/node_modules/resolve/lib/async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:95:15)
```

title: Add process.debug global when `--debug` is enabled
body:
It would work as a replacement to `NODE_ENV=development`, enabling libraries such as bluebird to detect it and turn on debug mode (long stack traces, helpful warnings etc)

Right now the only alternative is to both turn on `--debug` and use [envify](https://github.com/hughsk/envify), and thats not exactly beginner friendly.

```
browserify index.js -t [ envify --NODE_ENV development ] --debug > bundle.js
```

title: browserify applies transforms to npm linked modules
body:
Same bug as #1386, triggering for non-minimal use-cases:

If you npm link a module into your browserify project, it incorrectly has transforms applied to it, but only if a required module in the linked package requires another local module.

Opening new issue so it doesn't get lost as reopening closed issues require admin attention.
See #1437 for a failing testcase.

title: \ufeff character problem
body:
I use browserify to bundle my *.js and *.html files into single bundle.js. I'm really confused about next character in my template:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1132431/11342017/34ab677e-9216-11e5-9abd-5f111f4e819a.png)
I've checked it in bundle.js, here is:

``` javascript
function(e,t,n){t.exports="\ufeffhello"},{}
```

This is result of sourcemaps:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1132431/11342167/ff0913a4-9216-11e5-9d98-d9460d5c7ed3.png)

I removed sourcemap creating, uglifying but this character still here.

I tried to change `html-browserify` to `stringify`, but the problem wasn't solved.

Here is notepadd++ content of fables.list.html file, special charactes: on, encoding: utf-8-bom, length 5:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1132431/11342307/be43db46-9217-11e5-9e5d-00d7d2af4d6c.png)

That's my current gulp.task:

``` javascript
var gulp = require('gulp'),    
    browserify = require('browserify'),
    html = require('html-browserify'),
    source = require('vinyl-source-stream'),
    buffer = require('vinyl-buffer'),
    uglify = require('gulp-uglify'),
    sourcemaps = require('gulp-sourcemaps'),
    clean = require('gulp-clean');

gulp.task('browserify', function () {
    return browserify({ entries: 'client/app/js/app.module.js' })
        .transform(html)
        .bundle()
        .pipe(source('bundle.js'))
        .pipe(gulp.dest('client/dist/js'));
});
```

title: using browserify with electron
body:
I'm building react based desktop pplication with github electron. Electron allow to use node.js features in browser code. However I still need browserify for compile react files.

The issue is that with standard browserify policies node code goes invalid. `require` no longer work as expected, `__filename` and `__dirname` start showing things which is not close to 'on-disk' reality, etc.

Is there is any kind of vision how it's possible to friend electron with browserify?

title: browserified.require() but only if the exposed name was required
body:
Let's say I use the API somewhat like this:

``` js
browserified = browserify(...);
browserified.require('./........./something.js', {expose: 'monkey'});
```

Let's say I call the second line in a loop or from some config, etc. and the exposed name isn't necessarily the same as anything in the path.

Is there a way I can get it so it's only included in the bundle if it is actually `require`d in the bundle? As far as I can tell I have these options:
- `require` it by it's path in my bundle but this is not good enough. I need to be able to require it by the exposed name.
- `require` it by exposed name. Analyse the bundle with [detective](https://github.com/substack/node-detective) to get what's `require`d and call `browserified.require` for each of the files required.

If there was a way to specify a mapping between custom exposed names and filepaths, or a custom function to resolve the string which is `require`d, that would be good. I feel this is possible and must be there already, but I just can't see it in the docs.

title: See a list of bundled files
Setting stuff onto "this"
Added failing test: browserify still transforms symlinked modules
body:
This is a failing test showing that #1386 wasn't properly fixed.
The problem is that while symlinked modules containing a single file works, any subsequent relative requires made from that module are still being transformed, breaking any non-trivial example.

body:
I need to be able to provide generated content as dependencies to bundles

during build (using api) I know what the generated content will be, but there's no file containing it. it's only in memory. so i want to provide it to the bundle requiring it.

I can indeed do 

```
bundle.exclude('a');
bundle.require(stream, {expose:'a',file:'a.js'});
```

but this means my bundle ends up with 'a' even when it's not required.
any tips ?

```
Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/home/ivang/dev/test_browserify/browserify-bug/esprima'
    at Error (native)
```

But if you do `cp node_modules/jsonpath/package.json.working node_modules/jsonpath/package.json` browserify work as expected.

title: Same source different bundles generated
body:
Today while working on react app I noticed a problem where check for instance of the class was resulting in `false` when react checked for correct Prop Types passed in component, basically this:

```
model instanceof Model
```

I needed to generated bundle twice (in two different locations of the project) out of the same source code just with some changes in global frontend variables (configuration js file). The first one worked fine while the other faulted on validation of expected class.

It was a surprise seeing this while debugging (through sourcemaps) when the constructor function of instance and class were indeed same thing pointing at the same file, same line and there was only one class with this name in bundle, but still `model instanceof Model == false`. Then I checked the bundles. They were very different. I figured that module ids for this class were different, although they were pointing to the same file location. The catch was in the name of the folder, the second module Id key contained one uppercase symbol because one of the `import` statements in source code had the first letter of the folder in caps. Interesting that the first bundle didn't have a dup module.

We develop on windows machines. This problem is not obvious for windows users especially when this works in first case and doesn't in the second. Hopefully, I know what the problem is now but I'm not the only one developer there. So, I wonder if browserify has an option to overcome this in future that maybe checks the platform and lowercases the path keys for windows. 

Thanks.

title: ignore and exclude handle relative paths differently
body:
You can see it in the code here: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/bbfabaa77fd18e81fe4fd74e104a8a793660f5c5/index.js#L259-L279

They shouldn't handle relative paths differently, though fixing it would be a breaking change. At the very least the differences ought to be documented.

I think the behavior of `exclude` is much more intuitive. `ignore` only treats paths that begin with `.` as relative.

title: Pass external option to browserify() api method
body:
I'm using gulp and laravel-elixir for my build process. I can pass options through to the browserify() api method. I'm trying to remove duplication between two different bundles.

Running browserify(main.js, {require: 'files}) works as expected; however, browserify.js('second.js', {exclude: 'file'}) does not.

It looks like the require option works because of https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L92-L94 .

Would it be possible to make it work for exclude? Is there a way to do it without manually running the external() api method?

title: Can browserify API leverage the configs in package.json?
browserify transforms get applied twice
body:
This is a follow-up question from nikku/karma-browserify#152 regarding the behaviour of transforms. 

> If you specify transforms in your package and then apply the same ones via the API, they run 2x.

There is a [workaround](https://github.com/nikku/karma-browserify/issues/130#issuecomment-120036815) for that, but I'm not sure if running 2x is the desired behaviour...

Would be nice if that pitfall is covered by browserify. Having declared transforms 2x can be a valid use-case.

title: .jsx extensions not working after upgrade
browserify in the middle of .pipe() chain (gulp)
Transforms not being applied on .require()'d file
body:
I originally posted this issue over at [babelify](https://github.com/babel/babelify/issues/147), but I have the feeling it's actually more general.

I've created a repo to showcase this issue, it can be found at https://github.com/chielkunkels/browserify-issue. Deleting line 16 in the gulpfile (https://github.com/chielkunkels/browserify-issue/blob/master/gulpfile.js#L16) get rid of the error during bundling. While it can easily be omitted here, that's not the case for the code I actually need it for.

Hope there's some kind of fix for this. Cheers!

title: Fix badly formed module paths on Windows
body:
This addresses the issue raised in #1358.

It ensures 'required' modules have the expected path, i.e. `require("/apps/Call")` instead of `require("/apps\\Call")`.

title: Fix paths in example of multiple bundles
body: Also replaced dir name `static` with `bundle` to make it clear those are the bundle files generated by browserify, not the source files.

Hi there,

First off, thanks for all the hard work on this amazing library, I've used browserify for a long time now and always managed to solve whatever it was that needed solving.

However, I've been struggling with this issue for a few days now, so I decided to distill it down to its most basic form to make sure I'm not a complete idiot. I've made a repository to showcase the issue I've been having: https://github.com/chielkunkels/browserify-issue

I hope this helps. It's doing my head in.

title: npm command fails if basedir refers a location outside working directory
body:
This [application](https://github.com/my3D-Team/js-html-kanban) works fine when running `npm run build` command. The `package.json` file configures the following command to be executed:

> browserify --debug app/js/main.js  | exorcist app/bundle.js.map | uglifyjs -cm > app/bundle.js

If I modify this command to execute browserify with `basedir` option, it will continue to work until I specify a location outside the working directory (where the command is executed). I created branch to reproduce the issue [here](https://github.com/my3D-Team/js-html-kanban/tree/issue-basedir).
In this branch I just moved the `package.json` file in a sub directory called `nodeapp` and modified the command to be executed:

> browserify --debug ./app/js/main.js --basedir ../ | exorcist app/bundle.js.map | uglifyjs -cm > app/bundle.js

When I move to the `nodeapp` directory and execute `npm run build`, I obtain this mysterious error:

> Parsing file App.react.js: Unexpected token (50:20)

Seems in that case browserify does not rely on reactify to transform the file.

Any ideas?

title: KEEP-A-CHANGELOG format
body:
Reformatted (most) of the changelog according to the guidelines described in http://keepachangelog.com.  

Basically, here's a quick summary: 
- it groups changes in a more human-friendly way
- adds the date of each release (here, dates were taken from npm)
- link each version to the URL showing the changes (which is awesome)

There were a few releases which could not be easily converted to the Keep-A-Changelog format.  
I left these notes as they were.

title: Buffer 3.5.0 broken (required by XMLHttpRequest shim)
body:
Today I ran into feross/buffer/issues/79 (Cannot set property length of [object Object]), when browserifying code, which made use of XMLHttpRequest.

(You'll need to run `npm test` on [my ajar clone](https://github.com/Ryuno-Ki/ajar/tree/mocha) after commenting line 2, where I require `xmlhttprequest`).

As stated there, the issue could be found on browserify-site as well. Please consider downgrading buffer import in [your package.json](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/b7cf5bef990a6823d14e2d437e15112aa6b3adfa/package.json#L28) until the issue is solved.

title: Dep round trip
body: This fixes https://github.com/jsdf/browserify-incremental/issues/22, which arises because `dep` events come with a row that can't be fed back into the cache.  This happens in the case when you have a file that is both exposed and required under its exposed name in the same bundle (which seems like it ought to be valid, and works fine without setting the cache option).

Lib: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/release-0_11/src/node.
Npm package: grpc.

Is it possible to support this library browserifying? Thanks.

title: Mostly streams3 updates (should be v12)
body:
The commits are pretty self-explanatory.

For the changelog:

```
#12.0.0

Node support changes: now testing against the latest node (currently 4.2.1). node 0.8 is no longer supported, and iojs isn't actively tested.

Stream3 everywhere! Everything has been updated to use streams3.

Sourcemaps charset now uses an `=` instead of a `:`. This fixes certain issues with Chinese characters in sourcemaps. See #753.

module-deps has been updated to fix root transforms on symlinked modules. See https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/99.

stream-http, the module that provides `http` support, dropped IE8 support. If you depend on this, see https://github.com/jhiesey/stream-http#ie8-note.

Removed `builtins` and `commondir` – both unused dependencies.
```

It would be pretty neat if browserify could ingest that sourcemap to have correct mapping from ES 2015 -> ES5 -> Browserify -> Source

For example UlgifyJS2 supports this with a "--in-source-map" option.
https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2

title: Compiling Order
npm 3.3.8 and Browserified modules
body:
I have a module with transforms defined in the package.json so that when I require this module elsewhere the necessary transforms get applied. This has broken since I updated to npm 3.3.8. The problem is that when the new package.json file is written after the npm install, the browserify transforms are no longer in the correct order. For example I use

``` json
"browserify": {
   "transform": ["jadeify", "babelify", "brfs"]
}
```

but after installed it is

``` json
"browserify": {
   "transform": ["babelify", "brfs", "jadeify"]
}
```

Which doesn't work because babel can't parse the jade files. It looks like the problem originates from here: https://github.com/npm/npm/blob/master/lib/utils/deep-sort-object.js#L6 and https://github.com/npm/npm/blob/master/lib/install/update-package-json.js#L14

I opened an issue with npm as well but thought you guys might want to know about this since it breaks a sort of important feature of browserify.

Issue with npm: https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/10063

title: Problem with request module
body:
Could not build javascript (using require module) application with browserify because:

```
Error: Cannot find module '../C:\Users\oakio\AppData\Roaming\nvm\v0.12.7\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\insert-module-globals\node_modules\is-buffer\index.js' from 'c:\Projects\reqtest\node_modules\request\node_modules\combined-stream\lib'
    at C:\Users\oakio\AppData\Roaming\nvm\v0.12.7\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:55:21
    at load (C:\Users\oakio\AppData\Roaming\nvm\v0.12.7\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:69:43)
    at onex (C:\Users\oakio\AppData\Roaming\nvm\v0.12.7\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:92:31)
    at C:\Users\oakio\AppData\Roaming\nvm\v0.12.7\node_modules\browserify\node_modules\resolve\lib\async.js:22:47
    at FSReqWrap.oncomplete (fs.js:95:15)
```

Steps to reproduce:
Create app.js with simple content:

```
var req = require('request');
req.get('http://google.com', function (e, r) {
});
```

Next create package.json:

```
{
  "name": "reqtest",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "Test",
  "main": "app.js",
  "dependencies": {
    "babelify": "^6.3.0",
    "request": "^2.65.0"
  },
  "browserify": {
    "transform": [
      "babelify"
    ]
  }
}
```

And run 
`browserify app.js > bundle.js`

Enviroment:

> OS: Windows 7 x64 
> nodejs: v0.12.7 
> npm: v2.11.3
> browserify v11.2.0
> request v2.65.0

[Related](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33217411/browserify-cannot-find-module-insert-module-globals-node-modules-is-buffer-inde)

title: Remove unnecessary workaround to hide full path
body:
This was previously added in 5fe121b to prevent the absolute path to the "process" module from exposed in the bundle.

Recently a [change landed in _insert-module-globals_](https://github.com/substack/insert-module-globals/pull/54) that prevents this from happening in the first place by using relative paths instead of absolute paths, thus this workaround is no longer needed.

This is technically a breaking change for those who are calling `require("_process")` directly (which should not happen as it was never advertised as a public api). Should probably wait for a major version release anyway.

**There are currently failing tests:** 

```
    not ok 2 - cwd directory visible
      ---
      found: 2675
      wanted: -1
      compare: ===
      at:
        file: test/leak.js
        line: 32
        column: 11
      source: |
        t.equal(src.indexOf(process.cwd()), -1, 'cwd directory visible');
      stack: >
        test/leak.js:32:11
        ...
```

This is because the test checks for the existence of `process.cwd()` in the bundle, which exists because the basedir of the bundle is set to `/tmp/...` and the relative path from `/tmp/...` to where the process module is happens to include the `process.cwd()` substring in it: `../../../home/parshap/projects/node-browserify/node_modules/process/browser.js`.

I'm not sure what the right approach is here.
1. Is this ok, or we are allowing too much to be exposed in the odd case that the bundle basedir is in a completely different directory than where the browserify `node_modules` directory is?
2. If it's ok, how should the test be changed? Should this assertion be removed?
3. If it's not ok, should we add the same kind of workaround for `Buffer.isBuffer` (e.g., add a `require("_is-buffer")` builtin)?

title: remove unnecessary whitespace
body: Only deleted the unnecessary whitespace, nothing else!

title: Version bump
body:
The outdated `stream-http@1.7.1` has a dependency on the  deprecated
`indexof@0.0.1` package. See also: https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1402

title: Bumping labeled-stream-splicer version
body: Eliminates dependency on obsolete `indexof@0.0.1` (deprecated by `component-indexof`) in outdated sub-depedency `stream-splicer@1.3.2`.

title: Bumped dep to commondir@1.0.1
body: Fixes warning about non-SPDX license usage in commondir@0.0.1

title: Require module with --require flag in node
body: Is it possible to require a module which has used the --require flag from within a node context?

title: Incorrect generated code for local --require'd modules
body:
If we have two files `a.js` and `b.js` with `require('./b')` inside `a.js`, and then build with

```
browserify --exclude ./b a.js > main.js
browserify --require ./b > lib.js
```

and include with

```
<script src="lib.js"></script>
<script src="main.js"></script>
```

we get an error `Cannot find module './b'`. That's because `lib.js` contains only `"/b"` as a key of its internal map. Though it's possible to workaround with `require('/b')`, this is in no way expected behaviour.

title: Release proposal: browserify 12.0.0
body:
Proposing a new major browserify release (12.0.0) with the following changes:
- MAJOR: bump stream-http to 2.0.0 (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1384)
- travis: test on node 4.x not 4.0.0 (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1396)
- doc: fix link to querystring (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1393)
- buffer: enforce at least 3.4.3 to prevent old bug (https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1362)

Leaving this open for at least 5 days to solicit feedback. Are there any other important changes to include?

title: Unlock transform limitations for node_modules
body:
Hello,

We use a lot of npm modules as front end packages for distribution (we don't use bower to limit the number of Tools to learn or install).
Browserify is limited because you must add a package.json containing:

```
"browserify": {
  "transform": [
    "babelify"
  ]
}
```

But when I add those lines to my package.json I get this error:
dest.on('unpipe', onunpipe);
       ^
TypeError: undefined is not a function
    at DestroyableTransform.Readable.pipe from through2 module

What is the problem because if I replace the node_modules folder with node_mod for example, all is working perfectly?

It would be great to make the difference between frontend package and module library package like this:

```
import * from "browserify/myfile"; // this is a Library module so exclude from transform
```

```
import * from "./node_modules/browserify/myfile"; // this is a frontend package
// so include in transform because we are using the full path to the file
```

Hope this could be possible because it drives me crazy if I will have to add lines to all my frontend package.json.

Thanks in advance for your help.

title: Links to the wrong querystring module
body: Previously linked to `querystring` while it actually depends on `querystring-es3`

title: do not apply root transforms on linked modules
body:
Incudes tests from #1365 and fixes #1365 , fixes #1386.

This _will_ fail until https://github.com/substack/module-deps/pull/99 is merged and released on module-deps. I'll re-run when that's done.

title: Only use entry files for standalone export
body:
If I want to to use `require('foo')` in my code, I do `browserify().require('./foo', {expose: 'foo'})`. Just because I do that, doesn't mean I want that to now be an entrypoint of my app, I just want it to be a library available internally.

Fixes #1390
Fixes #1120

This breaks backwards compatibility for people solely using `require()` (which I think is an error since there is not entry files). Change the one that was highest number to an `add()` and it will work as before.

title: standalone - highest number always wins
body: If I have two entry files, then the one with the highest module number always ends up being the standalone file. Can we make this deterministic instead? First file added? The ones added by `add()` and not `require()`? Just something so I can control it.

title: indexDeps swallows deps
body:
https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/master/index.js#L685

In some cases, the indexDeps do not equal the deps and this change makes browserify unable to resolve what the non index files.

title: browserify applies transforms to npm linked modules
body:
If you `npm link` a module into your browserify project, it incorrectly has transforms applied to it. This becomes a major issue particularly if the module you install relies on non-strict mode and you're using babelify, which inserts `"use strict"`, causing it to error.

Here's a repo to reproduce: https://github.com/jayphelps/browserify-bug. The major step to note in the README is that you must git clone the external module and `npm link` it for the bug to show.

Also note that very new versions of babel proactively transform certain strict mode code, like `this.foo` to `undefined.foo`. Don't let this confuse you.

title: How to only exclude 'process' from global vars
body:

```
}
```

title: bump stream-http version to 2.0.0
body:
This version of stream-http omits reimplementations of es5 functions
for ie8. The suggested polyfills, or a full set like es5-shim, are
now needed to use `http` in ie8.

title: Depending on a browserified module causes "module not found" errors
body:
I have a module that I am trying to build with browserify. The module has a dependency, whose main export is a file that is also built with browserify. When I run browserify on the upstream module, it tries to resolve `require` statements _inside the distribution file of a dependency_. Because these point to files relative to the source of the dependency, they can't be found, and the build fails.

Example:

**lib**

```
dist.js
package.json
src/
  index.js
  other-file.js
```

`index.js` contains `require('./other-file')` and `package.json` contains `main: "dist.js"`.

**upstream**

```
package.json
index.js
node_modules
  lib
```

`index.js` contains `require('lib');`. Running browserify on it produces the error "can't find module './other-file' from 'lib'".

Is this by design or a bug? How do I get around it?

title: Browserify cannot find module with 'require(module_name)'
browserify adds the '.' in case you forget it (#649 fix)
body:
All the extension options will automatically have a `.` pretended to the argument, if one is not already present. Fixed this issue according to this [comment](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/issues/649#issuecomment-34950912)

Let me know how it looks! :smile:

title: ES6 & Dead Code Elimination
body:
I recently got pointed [rollup](https://github.com/rollup/rollup), which produces clean builds by assuming the source is using ES6 import/export. It then can mash all the modules into the same closure, instead of the current `browser-pack` approach that tends to produce a lot of extra boilerplate and closures. It can also tree-shake unused functions.

It would be worth exploring whether something similar is possible in browserify (or, as a plugin/transform independently of browserify). 

Big things to figure out:
- a means of resolving to ES6 source for packages written in ES6 and pre-published to ES5. Right now rollup uses `esnext:main` which isn't exactly standard, and maybe could be named better (i.e. what happens with ES7?). It would also be good to have other bundlers like jspm and webpack agree on the same approach.
- how to take the rollup approach (single closure) rather than `bundle-pack` approach (closure per module) and what kind of problems this might impose

title: default entry file to `.`
body:
Presently, browserify (CLI) requires an entry file to start as the entrypoint.

```
$ browserify
Usage ...
```

Of course, the entrypoint file is typically specified via `browserify index.js`. In package.json, a typical build script might look like:

```
"build": "browserify $npm_package_main"
```

Apparently, since node already knows how to resolve the default file in a directory, `.` can be supplied to browserify as the entry as well:

```
"build": "browserify ."
```

Since node (and apparently browserify, as well) can accept a directory as an entrypoint; it would be nice if browserify simply defaulted to `.` as the entrypoint if not specified via the command line.

I would love my build script to be:

```
"build": "browserify -o $npm_package_config_buildfile"
```

title: Compatible With  RequireJS
noParse does not seem to be working
body:
I pass a noParse array to browserify but it does not seem to be working.

Following the source code, on a file which should not be parsed, in `Deps.walk()` it calls `self.resolve`, which reads the file contents and passes it to `fromSource`, which always calls `self.parseDeps` as `rec.noparse` is never set (that I can see). I don't know how to workaround this issue either...

title: Browser attribute is not parse correctly in required modules
body:
The problem is as follow:

Given a module that defines the browser attribute inside it's `package.json` and required inside a project works as expected.

But when the same module is required from another module which is used directly in the project's `package.json` it bundles the node version.

Example:

Requiring [superagent](https://github.com/visionmedia/superagent) in a project works as expected, but requiring [backbone-super-sync](https://github.com/artsy/backbone-super-sync/blob/master/package.json) bundles the node version of [superagent](https://github.com/visionmedia/superagent) instead of the client one

title: How to expose the entry file ?
Add failing test for top level transforms and symlinked node modules
body:
Adds a failing test with using a transform on top-level files on symlinked node modules. 

The test failure is coming from [passing in the realpath](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/blob/f7e626ca75bd925a584f9b0fe8ff9d4b8e90f188/index.js#L486) and `module-deps` uses this path to [determine if the file is top level](https://github.com/substack/module-deps/blob/9112e326d76a97869ecffee06d84be21e6f7d157/index.js#L200-L216).

A possible solution is to not pass in the realpath and calculate it instead in `module-deps`. I think this makes sense as `module-deps` would want to know the realpath **and** the resolved path of the file.

title: Fails if a function named `delete` exists in the file
Unicode in source map paths displays incorrectly in Chrome
body:
I've found some heisenbug in Google Chrome that likely annoys users of `browserify` and I need some help.

When
- `browserify` creates a bundle with source maps and
- some module is located on a path with cyrillic letters in it and
- source map is included via data URI (everything's OK with separate source map) and
- HTML page including the bundle is loaded from server (`file:\\` URI are OK)

in Chrome DevTools / Sources tab / tree view displays paths incorrectly, as if it was trying to show UTF-8 as 1252.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2983969/9451137/7a6dc5ac-4ab5-11e5-9c3d-d954b6664d7f.png)

Generated source map is perfectly fine, as I've checked with Notepad++ hex editor plugin.

I had an idea that I don't know something about HTTP encoding headers that should be set when serving `*.js` files, but I've found no evidence of this in RFC specs as JavaScript has `application/javascript` MIME-type and as every `application/*` shouldn't be bothered by HTTP.

Do you have the same issue running an [attached example](https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BzMKD__MPU47MVptOFhBWDI0akE/view?usp=sharing)?
Is there something wrong with my `express` server config and it's not a bug at all?

title: bump buffer to 3.4.3 to fix maximum call stack exceeded errors
body:
Many modules are reporting `maximum call stack exceeded` errors (at least in Chrome) that were due to a bug in the `buffer` module.
eg:
- https://github.com/evanw/node-source-map-support/issues/95
- https://github.com/feross/buffer/pull/70

This PR simply bumps buffer to the 3.4.3 revision and has fixed the source maps problem as well as another problem I came across in auth0's lock module.

All tests pass with this bump

title: global var insertion fixes
body:
- Fix `--bare` and `--igv`
- Exclude `process` and `buffer` when `bundleExternal === false`

title: Broken watchify with version > 3.3.1
body: Changes from watchify lib version 3.3.0 to 3.3.1 have broken the watchify feature.

title: Browserify doesn't use project's `node_modules` directory when using symlink
body: I have a shared module called `foo` that I include in my project's node_modules directory via npm link. In the `foo` module, I have a `require('react')` statement where 'react' is included as a peer dependency in my project's node_modules. When using Browserify 9.0.8 everything works fine, but upgrading to 11.0.0 I get the error `Cannot find module 'react'`.

title: .require() with expose: true use backslashes on Windows
body: When using [.require()](https://github.com/substack/node-browserify#brequirefile-opts) method on Windows with the `expose:true` flag, the IDs are being generated with backslashes, like `/apps\\Call` instead of `/apps/Call`, so later they can't be found when `require()`ing them because they are not found. I think this is somewhat related to https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/503/files and https://github.com/substack/node-browserify/pull/1096/files and probably the fix would be the same, just replace the backslashes previously to set the path at the browserify output.

title: `bundler.require` with non js file does not call transforms
Exposing module within the built file.
body:
I'm trying to load a browserify built file into an app using requirejs, even using the `--standalone` option requirejs breaks and gives an unhelpful error message. I've noticed that built file returns a require function e.g.

``` javascript
var require = (/* browserify bundle here */);
require("12"); // returns the module with index 12 as given by module-deps output
```

I'm currently using a brittle script to work out the index of the module I'd like to expose and feel like the transform should be done in the pipeline rather than after browserify writes to the file system.

Would it be possible to have some kind of expose flag that took certain modules, and used a given string rather than their index as the ID? 
Maybe something like `browserify -e main.js -o bundle.js --expose ./app.js:app`

``` javascript
var require = (/* browserify bundle here */);
require("app"); // returns the "./app.js" module (relative to where browserify was run)
```

I'm happy to do the work and PR it but wondering if it's something you'd consider accepting. If not, is the browserify specific code anywhere so I can pipe through module-deps -> browser-pack -> browserify and intercept in the middle?
